comments.commentBody:
Xwrdinfo appears to be down. I can't get there anyway.

Great wordplay made this a fun puzzle.
Can you please document that Sanders took money from the NRA?  Neither Clinton nor any of the moderators made that claim.
The problem with Senator Sanders is that he does not understand much about the Middle East.  He sounds very naive.   Sen Clinton knows better than anyone that Netanyahu isn't always right.

I'm surprised there is no mention of the heated exchange on Israel. It's rare to hear a candidate be so bold as to dare criticize Israel and speak directly to the humanity of the Palestinians in a presidential debate as did Sanders.

People need to wake up and question why we keep giving Israel billions. Its a terrible mess and there are good arguments (or rather bad arguments) on all sides, but has anyone noticed that in the meantime we just keep throwing American dollars away?

Al that ever happens is we give money away for no reason, and don't spend on social issues that matter to ordinary Americans.

I, for one, am very pleased to finally hear an Amercian politician tell the truth on the issue, instead of the usual unilateral support of a country that is guilty - and has been deemed so by the UN and other International agencies on 200+ counts - of crimes against humanity

I thought Sanders gave the same left wing knee jerk response. Of course, Palestinians should be treated with dignity and respect. But how would he get Hamas to stop calling for the extermination of all the Jews in Israel. How would he get Abbas to do... anything including run for re-election as he is now in his tenth year of a five year term. Bernie is good with sound bites, but never the details.

The most revealing part of the debate came when Bernie Sanders said that if elected he would withdraw the nomination of Merrick Garland to the Supreme Court and nominate a candidate willing to pledge to overturn the Citizens United decision.  Like Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, I believe that Citizens United was wrongly decided and has produced terrible results.  But to impose a litmus test on a Supreme Court nominee to overturn precedent is no different than the Republicans who will support only nominees who pledge to overturn Roe v. Wade.  Senator Sanders's response showed a disregard for judicial independence, and for President Obama's judgment.  More important, it underscored that he is candidate with a very limited focus, and a naive view of Congressional politics.  No wonder he has been unable to accomplish anything of substance in all his years in the Senate.

If he wants to offer great things, he should articulate his plan for getting them done.  If he cannot understand that getting anything done anywhere is compromise, do you really think he will accomplish anything?

Your statement at the end in the last paragraph demonstrates that you have not researched the Amendment King. Please actually review his record and the things he has advocated. Begin with his support of civil rights while Hillary was a self serving goldwater girl/walmart board member.

Just to remind you, Goldwater voted against the civil rights act.

us army 1969-1971/california jd
This would be overturning a  law for which there is no precedent!

Still not getting what the big deal is about Clinton's speaking fees. Different tiers of speakers command different speaking fees -- such is the market for speaking engagements. Should Secretary Clinton have given Goldman Sachs a discount? Done it out of charity? I don't get it.

Furthermore, I highly, highly doubt that anyone on Wall Street thinks that they have her in the pocket because of $675,000 in speaking fees. I hate to break it to you, but I know tech support guys who made more than that in annual bonuses (in good years).

Sanders won't be listing any speaking fees on his 2014 tax returns, as he proudly stated. This might be because, as an ineffective senator from Vermont, nobody would have paid him money to hear him speak. It's not as though he had a choice and made a decision -- demand was zero, price was zero. Market forces in action.

No offense, but I have to agree that you don't get it.

Clinton's speaking fees are an obvious conflict of interest with her stated intention to protect America from the further abuses of the Wall Street banks. They gave her over $11 million in speaking fees, not the $675,000 that you quote. I hate to break it to you, but those guys don't invest money without expecting a great deal in return.

The New York Times itself has stated in an editorial that she should release the transcripts about what she said in these speaking engagements; she knows she cannot do that and retain the possibility of being a viable candidate.

That's what the big deal is about Clinton's speaking fees. They mean that she is for sale, and she is being deceitful and duplicitous about it. Although you may not think that is unusual for a politician, that is something that many feel should change.

Oh, and by the way, Sanders was not an ineffective senator from Vermont, although this newspaper, and Clinton's supporters, would love you to believe that, and they have made quite an effort to actively denigrate his efforts and achievements.

U.S. senators are barred by the Code of Official Conduct (Senate Rules 34-43) from accepting honoraria (fees, etc.) for speeches. Interesting that Sanders chooses not to mention this while attacking Clinton for speeches given as a private citizen.
it's illegal silly

Sanders voiced a vision for an America, what we should strive for though it may be difficult to achieve.  Clinton spoke only of incrementalism. I think it's fair to say America faces too many serious challenges to be satisfied with the latter -- a leader who preaches patience to those of us who have been waiting far too long for our voices to be heard.
I'm confused, is this a plug for improved children's fitness or the junior senator from VT?
"Visions" or delusion?

Clinton represents reality all right. The reality of PACs, politicians on the take, corporate welfare, incomprehensible foreign policy, and most egeregious of all, a stagnant economy and continuing industrial flight for banana republics with low wages.

I'm with the socialist, the one who has all those "too big to do" ideas. I'll take the risk going with him down that road. We have been stuck with four flat tires for far too long.

Very true, Steve, but the Republicans don't differ in their determination to ostracize women and abortion providers, yet they keep trying to outdo each other.  From the "punishment" quips to characterizing Planned Parenthood as criminal, to actually defunding it, in-state, they don't offer real variation in thought.  So the leaders who will speak up for our rights and privacy should be as vocal and should sound the alarm over the encroachments.  Thank you for taking the time to reply to my post.  Best regards.
Clinton proclaiming Obama and using him as a crutch just has a very unsavory characteristic about it - its such an inauthentic and blatant ploy.  I wish she would just be a human and not a BOT.

Politically, the only thing Clinton has going for her, IMO, is all the Republican conspiracy theories about her, and the way they behave toward her.  Of course if Sanders is the nominee, he'll soon draw the same ''right wing conspiracy','' and the same advantage.

"Clinton proclaiming Obama and using him as a crutch just has a very unsavory characteristic about it"

That is especially true because he defeated her on real issues, and she hasn't changed. She is using him to push the same things he opposed her one when he defeated her.

I found that Clinton kept looking back at Obama's performance and trying to portray it as her doing while Sanders kept looking forward and telling us what he plans to do.

I want someone with future ambitions and not someone resting on another man's coattails

I think I've watched most, if not all debates. I've lost my count.

I like to summarize my thoughts on what the candidates say during the debates. Today, I realized that I've learned nothing new, except that Bernie got murdered in the very conservative deep South.

Oh wait, I am in the deep South. Who murdered Bernie in the deep South?

I will vote for Hillary Clinton.

YES!!!
His discounting Democrats in the South which make up
what 40% African American.. I find his views on that,
repugnant.
He needs to STOP saying those things about the South.

Clinton got Meaningless Red State votes. So far, 12 out of the 18 states that HRC has won in the 2016 primaries are Red states that will remain Red in the 2016 election. This means that ~4.9 million primary votes that HRC got in Red states are meaningless as far as electing a Dem. POTUS.

Bernie`s wins/votes are in Blue & Purple states that will contribute to the Electoral college total that will assure him of becoming POTUS. Eg. He has only ~2.4 million votes from these same 12 Red states. That difference accounts for the oft touted 2.4 million votes that Clinton supporters quote but like HRC are meaningless. In addition the Dem party doesn't count individual votes in caucuses which Bernie wins hands down.

HRC is totally owned by AIPAC & Wall St which frequently are the same people. As most of the American people know/feel she is not trustworthy & will not represent them but rather her owners.

Hillary CRUSHED him in Florida.. that's a Swing State..

as for Blue States.. Umm, they are Blue for a REASON....
That means they will vote Blue, no matter who.

Where do you people get these ideas? The Southern votes don't matter?

also, Bill Clinton won Arkansas. So, could turn a Red State Blue
Please, enough debates. Neither of them said anything new. Familiarity is breeding contempt-for both of them.

But what has Hillary done except try to buy them the vote raising more money from billionaires? Bernie just gave his support to three progressive women one of who is being attacked by the Clinton machine in favor of a more bribible candidate. He has even gone so far as to start a co-fundraising programs for them...

Hillary dodged and evaded questions on carbon tax, raising the social security cap and -- most crucially -- the transcripts of her speeches to Wall Street. She cannot commit to a position on three of the most important issues facing working class Americans today.

Bernie Sanders spoke truthfully and with verve and true NY grit. We all saw it. And Tuesday's results will show what a great job he did tonight, and how quickly the Clinton campaign is crumbling.

The number of delegates Hillary gets next Tuesday will be a reality check for you Bernie Supporters. And then there's New Jersey and Pennsylvania. There aren't enough Students and gun owners for Sanders to win.

And having a sugar daddy to pay off your student loans if elected President is as Pie in the Sky as Sanders' proposals. He's as predatory as the Wall Street Banks he complains about, keeping you thinking he's still in the race. It's all about keeping your $30 donations coming in. He's just another politician. Wake up and smell reality.

All the recent polls from NY have Hillary with double leads over Bernie. And, unlike the missed Michigan projections, these are recent polls. Polls taken after all his little caucus wins out West, and even his primary win in Wisconsin.

Hillary currently leads in NY, CT, PA, MD and CA with only CT being even remotely close.

Her campaign is hardly crumbling.
When it comes to choosing a president, I'll take "steely confidence" over "a ferocious performance" any day of the week.
You are really that influenced by the reporter's very calculated choice of vocabulary?
I saw her "core nastiness" and "do anything to win" nature exposed.

Way to choose a President based on subjective reporting from a journalist.

Like many reporters who had already written their accounts before the debate even began (traded barbs, feisty, sparred, the lazy metaphors go on and on), most comments here are simply reinforcing their own preconceived notions on the candidates.

I, however, live in a state that has yet to vote, and along with 40% of the country, still have the opportunity to weigh in on this race.

Polls, pundits, and reporters all want to call this race over, I simply ask for a little perspective and allow the process to play out.

I'm confident the American people will be able to sort it all out by July, and again in November.
On two occasions Sen. Sanders didn't seem to listen to Sec. Clinton's answers, acting like she didn't answer or said something else. Very odd.

When Bernie was Mayor of Burlington (right here in my backyard), he was known for his ability and willingness to work with those who were opposite him politically, including conservatives, Republicans, and business people.  As a result, he presided over a rejuvenation of the city that was (and is) heralded by a wide variety of its residents.  In VT, Bernie is widely popular across the spectrum due to his willingness to listen to and work with those he is in apparent disagreement with.
He's too busy waving his hands at women when they're talking to listen to what they're actually saying.
But he hasn't done that at all in Congress, Edgar, and is actually widely disliked by colleagues on both sides of the aisle. Don't see how he gets any of them to work with him as president.

Hillary may actually get things done. The USA is not Vermont and Bernie won't be able to get anything done. I rather move forward towards a fairer, more humane country in small steps than have chaos trying to do "big" things as Bernie dreams of doing.

Why don't you do us all a favor and explain HOW Hillary will accomplish anything when confronted with the very same Congress that you claim will prevent Sanders from governing? I keep hearing this trope with no follow-up. Where is her leverage? Does she wave a magic wand? Does she try to give away the store like Obama with his "Grand Bargain"? Or, being a Clinton does she possess incriminating videos of her GOP adversaries?
Read up on climate change.  Google James Hansen and other scientists.  Small steps are getting us into deep water (literally for our children and their children).

Well if getting things done for Wall Street, Goldman Sachs, Raytheon, Boeing, Lockheed-Martin and other gun manufacturers is a "move forward towards a fairer, more humane country in small steps" I have to say, I'd rather have nothing get done at all.

1. Regarding guns. Clinton doesn't seem to have any problems with the fact that her "friend" Kirstein Gillibrand had a worse record on gun control than Sanders did when she was a congresswoman from rural NY.
2. Why doesn't Clinton support raising the income limits on social security?
This would seem like a no brainer to anyone except the wealthy.
3. Clinton cites all the wonderful works she did as secretary of state. It reminds me of the old Tom Lehrer song where he sang "Let's make peace they we did in Stanleyville and Saigon." If one were to listen to her you'd think she brought peace to the middle east.
And I didn't hear one statement from her of how, with all her experience, she would bring peace there and defeat Isis. Sanders may not have the answer but neither does she nor anyone else.

She did say she would raise the Cap...

She also said we would do other things as well.

Hillary hit it nail on by telling Sanders diagnosing wasn't enough. He says a lot but fails to provide an actual plan. Even on the criminal justice center - he speaks confidently about releasing 1/2 a million prisons, yet that decision lays at the state level not federal.

Hillary did a great job on the topic of gun control. Even as Sanders says he has a D- rating, other democrats have an F rating, so he is really at a B or so. It's all in prospective.
Bernie has laid out his plans  at the huge rally in New York on Wednesday...and at every rally. But, you won't hear about in the "rigged Media."
How can Clinton, who oversaw billions in arms sales to Saudi Arabia, qualify as someone who can talk about gun control?
He's laid out his plans, Andy, but not how to actually pay for them.

Sanders has explained his "support" because  Vermont has a large hunting population. I hate people who buy guns to hunt animals, but I hate people who buy guns to hunt people even more. There is a difference.

The adoration of Sanders has got to stop. Since when is it a voter's job to fall in love with a politician? Elect them to do a job, and then watch them like a hawk to hold them accountable. The suspension of critical thinking by Sanders' supporters isn't just vomit-inducing; it's dangerous.

She was weak on money accepted from Goldman Sachs for speeches, and  he was weak on gun-control.  Neither gave a satisfactory answer on those subjects.  He was excellent on Israel, and she was excellent on women (a topic she introduced).   If only they could be combined to make the almost-perfect candidate.

Excellent, on Israel? Hardly, he lost 2 votes yesterday - a die hard Bernie
supporter who was angered and repulsed by the Sander' position on Israel, and
an on the fence HRC supporter, who is now firmly in her camp.
Like the "almost-perfect"!

How is Sanders weak on the gun control issue? I think HRC took NRA money. He voted to ban assault weapons, and he has a D minus rating from the NRA. Imagine any other country having their politicians rated by the lobby for weapons! Surreal.

And Bernie has a point---should a small shop gun seller in a rural state like Vermont etc who sells a legal hunting rifle to someone not on a blacklist be sued if the customer shoots someone? This has to be discussed more fully.

Suddenly everybody is so big on gun control when it comes to Sanders. Really rich.
That is because both she and Sanders agree. They are both pro-choice.
They both agree on abortion, there's no debate there.

"NATO is crucial today, and US is its lynchpin. Without NATO, Russia might swallow Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, destabilizing all Europe."

That's probably a reasonable diagnosis, given that realty that exists today. But I think NATO's continuation and enlargement after the end of the cold war (the very reason for the organization's existence) was an historic mistake, perhaps worse even than invading Iraq. It was just as provocative to the Russians as a Russian-led treaty in this hemisphere would be to the United States. It was tailor-made to promote the rise to power of Putin or something like him.

Or, newly independent countries charted their own paths and chose to join NATO as their populations demanded.

Russia has never been given veto power over the internal affairs of other sovereign nations, not even when it tried to pulls the strings in Kiev.

How Russia perceives the NATO expansion is on them.

Fran,
Kirsten Gillibtand took NRA money when she was a congresswoman and opposed gun control measures. Do you intend on voting against her?
